The design and capabilities of GenApp are intentionally very simple. GenApp is designed to create a shell cFS application using simple string substitution. It's not solving a complex problem so it should be very easy to use, configure, extend, and maintain.
GenApp is given a base directory where template source files are located and a base target directory where the instantiated files are created. This property provides default template and target directories. These directory paths are relative to GenApp's working directory. The user can override these defaults.
This file defines properties used by the cFS Application Generation tool. Key string constants are defined in the tool.Constants.java source file.
The "template-var" entry defines case sensitive template variables that are replaced by GenApp with the new App's name. They template variables should not need to change but are defined as a property just in case.
Each template base directory must contain a file called. genapp-template.xml. This file tells genapp which subdirectories/files to instantiate. New application templates are easy to add by creating a directory hierarchy containing template files and an genapp-template.xml.
